1.title: Introduction to Basic 3D Primitives
1.content: Most simple objects can be broken down into basic 3D primitives or 2D profiles that follow a line.
1.caption2: Rectangular Prisms, indicated by the green bounding box
1.takeawayContent: When combined, these shapes can represent objects like a 9 volt battery

2.title: Less Common Primitives
2.content: These primitives can then be combined into larger and more complex objects:

3.title: 3D to 2D Correlation
3.content: • Basic primitives can be broken down into 2 dimensional shapes that flow along a line or revolve about a line. For example:
3.caption1: • A square along a line normal to it (Cube)
3.caption2: • A triangle that is rotated about one of its legs (Cone)
3.caption3: • A half circle rotated about it's straight edge (Sphere)

4.title: Shapes That Vary Along 2 Axes
4.content:
• Certain 3d shapes vary along two different axis, such as a spring, which consists of a 2d profile (a circle) along a 3 dimensional line (a helix).

  • Objects like these are a natural progression of the basic 3D primitives since they vary in two dimensions rather than 1.
4.takeawayContent:
• Notice a 2D profile rotated about an axis not intersecting itself (a Torus) can equivalently be described as a 2D profile (a circle) following a path (a second circle whose center is not within the 2d profile).

  • If this circular path were stretched along the axis normal to it, it would create a helix, and sweeping a 2d profile along this, like a circular profile, would create a spring.

5.title: Negative Space
5.content: In addition to positive space, these primitives may also be used to create negative space. When negative spaces are combined with positive space primitives they create hollow volumes. Examples:
5.caption1:
Pipe
A cylinder with a second negative space cylinder inside
5.caption2:
Basketball
A positive space sphere with a smaller negative space sphere inside
5.caption3:
Hole in a piece of wood
A rectangular prism with a negative space cylinder inside
5.caption4:
Bicycle Inner Tube
A torus with a smaller negative space torus inside

6.title: Combining Similar Primitives
6.content: • Often these primitives come in pairs and can be combined to create more complex volumes. A common volume made using multiple cylinders is a medicine bottle.
6.mediaTitle: This is made using the following progression:
6.caption1: 1. A positive cylinder making the main body (red)
6.caption2: 2. A negative smaller cylinder creating the cavity in the body (checkered)
6.caption3:
3. A larger diameter positive cylinder creating the cap (green) with a:
4. Smaller diameter negative space cylinder creating the inside of the cap (blue)

7.title: Combining Different Primitives
7.content: • Combining different types of basic primitives can yield more complex shapes that vary in all three dimensions.
7.mediaTitle: For example, a pill shape can be thought of as a cylinder with rounded ends. This consists of:
7.caption1:
A cylinder (red) making the main portion of the body
Two half spheres (blue) capping the ends

8.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Introduction
8.content: • These ideas are the building blocks of many common shapes around us. Let's apply this by taking a look at a more complex real-world shape: a Smart Switch.
8.takeawayContent:
For simplicity, assume the inside of the smart switch is solid. To break this down, we need to think about what basic primitives would be used to first fill the positive space, and then take away the negative space.

These basic primitives are:

  • Rectangular Prisms
  • Cylinders
  • Spheres
  • Wedges
  • 2D Profiles Swept Along A Path

9.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Rectangular Prisms
9.content: • Let's begin by looking at the Rectangular Prisms that make up the volume:
9.caption1: 1. The center of the body is made from one large Positive Space Rectangular Prism (+1, white) with 4 smaller Positive Space Rectangular Prisms flanking each side (+4, Red).
9.caption2: 2. Two smaller Positive Space Rectangular Prisms extend from the back, forming the metal tongs of the plug (+2, Green).
9.caption3: 3. Finally, three Negative Space Rectangular Prisms extend into the body from the front, giving an insertion point for a device to plug in to (-3, Blue).

10.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Cylinders I
10.content: • Next let's identify the cylinders that make up the volume:
10.caption1: 4. The 4 corners of the volume are filled in with 4 Positive Space quarter cylinders (+4, Yellow).
10.caption2: 5. One Negative Space cylinder extends into the body, giving room for the button (-1, Checkered).
10.caption3: 6. One Positive Space cylinder fills the hole made previously, making the button (+1, Light Green).

11.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Cylinders II
11.caption1: 7. Two Positive Space half cylinders form the tips of the rear prongs (+2, Blue).
11.caption2: 8. One Positive Space cylinder extends from the rear, forming the ground prong (+1, Purple)
11.caption3: 9. One more Negative Space cylinder extends into the body, forming the rest of the insertion point for a device to plug in to (-1, Checkered)

12.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Spheres
12.content: • Next let's identify the spheres that make up the volume:
12.caption1: 10A. A small portion of a large Negative Space sphere scallops the button (-1, Light Blue).
12.caption2: 10B. This shows the Negative Space sphere as pink.
12.caption3: 11. A Positive Space half cylinder caps off the ground prong on the rear (+1, Orange).

13.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Wedges
13.content: • Next let's identify the wedges that make up the volume:
13.caption1: 12. Two Negative Space wedges cut into each of the rear tongs to assist with guiding the tongs during insertion (-2x2=-4, Hot Pink).

14.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - 2D Profile Swept Along A Path
14.content: • Finally, let's identify the 2D Profile Swept Along a Path, the final feature that makes up this volume:
14.caption1: 13. A small square is swept along a path just offset from the front surface outer edge, creating a Negative Space (-1, Black).
14.takeawayContent:
Totalling these up, there are a net:
  • +4 Rectangular Prisms (1+4+2-3)
  • +6 Cylinders (4-1+1+2+1-1)
  • 0 spheres (1-1)
  • -4 wedges
  • -1 2D Profiles Swept Along A Path

15.title: Conclusion & Quiz Readiness
15.content:
• With these concepts in mind, look around the room and try to break down everyday objects into basic primitives — whether that be 2D shapes along a path or 3D primitives.
  • Most mechanical objects and simple items can be broken down into discrete shapes.
  • Once these shapes have been identified, modeling them and representing them digitally becomes a much easier next step.






    • To review the information again, press the learn button above. If you feel ready, press the next button to proceed to the quiz to test your knowledge.
